section: Definition of Onsen and Types of Spring Quality
content: An onsen (hot spring) refers to hot water, mineral water, steam, or similar that wells up from underground and meets certain standards for temperature and composition. Japan has many volcanoes, so hot spring resorts exist throughout the country. There are several types of spring quality, each with different characteristics. Simple hot springs have low stimulation and are suitable for children and the elderly, ideal for long baths and less prone to causing bath fatigue. Sulfur springs have a distinctive sulfur odor and are said to be good for skin conditions and cold sensitivity, but they are highly stimulating so caution is needed with long baths. Bicarbonate springs make it easier to remove dead skin cells and are often called "beauty skin springs"; after bathing, skin is said to feel smooth. Chloride springs have high heat-retention effects and are slow to cool down, making them suitable for those with cold sensitivity.

section: Kusatsu Onsen Overview and Spring Quality
content: Kusatsu Onsen is located in Gunma Prefecture and is one of Japan's Three Famous Springs, boasting the highest natural spring output in Japan. The spring quality is a strongly acidic spring with a pH of around 2, said to have high antibacterial properties, and has been passed down since ancient times as "curing everything except love sickness." Kusatsu Onsen has its own hot spring culture, with traditional bathing methods still practiced today: "yu-momi" (cooling high-temperature spring water without diluting it by stirring) and "awase-yu" (visiting baths of different temperatures in sequence). Historically, it was introduced by German physician Dr. Erwin Baelz as "a world-class hot spring health resort," and has been beloved by many cultural figures including Kobayashi Issa, Yosano Akiko, and Okamoto Taro.

Kusatsu Onsen is accessible by multiple means of transportation. The highway bus "Joshū Yumeguri-go" runs from Tokyo/Shinjuku via Busta Shinjuku, taking about 4 hours with fares from 3,700 yen to 4,100 yen for adults. There are also direct services from Yokohama, Omiya, Kawagoe, Takasaki, and others. By train, take the JR limited express "Kusatsu-Shima" from Ueno Station to Naganohara-Kusatsuguchi Station in about 2 hours 18 minutes, then take the JR bus to Kusatsu Onsen Bus Terminal in about 25 minutes (780 yen for adults). From Karuizawa Station, Kusakura Kotsu Bus or Seibu Kanko Bus is available (2,240 yen for adults). By car, it is about 163 km via Nerima IC and Shibukawa Ikaho IC. When visiting by car in winter, studless tires or tire chains are required.

section: Major Tourist Spots in Kusatsu Onsen
content: Yubatake in the center of Kusatsu Onsen is the symbol of Kusatsu, with about 4,000 liters of hot spring water gushing per minute. It is lit up from sunset until midnight, where you can enjoy the fantastical steam. Netsunoyu holds a traditional "yu-momi and dance" show daily, with an admission fee of 700 yen for adults. At night it also serves as the venue for "Kusatsu Onsen Rakugo." Sainokawara Park is a vast park with hot springs gushing from everywhere, free to stroll 24 hours, with lighting at night. The redeveloped Ura-Kusatsu Jizo area (2021) has foot baths, cafes, and an observation deck. The Onsen Gate completed in 2023 is Kusatsu Onsen's new entrance, adjacent to a large parking lot and equipped with foot baths.

section: Day-Trip Bathing Facilities in Kusatsu Onsen (Kusatsu Three Baths)
content: The three representative day-trip hot spring facilities in Kusatsu Onsen are called "Kusatsu Three Baths." Goza-no-Yu is a public bathhouse with beautiful wooden architecture near Yubatake. Otaki-no-Yu is a large facility where you can enjoy "awase-yu" (visiting baths of different temperatures in sequence), and on the 2nd and 4th Saturdays of each month it offers "milky water day" with cloudy spring water. Sainokawara Open-Air Bath is a vast open-air bath within the park, with impressive scale and openness. Every Friday night it becomes a mixed bath with swimwear. The "Choin San-yu Meguri Tegata" pass for economical use of all three facilities is sold for 2,100 yen for adults at each facility's reception.

section: Winter Precautions and Ski Resort in Kusatsu Onsen
content: In winter at Kusatsu Onsen, average temperatures drop below freezing, so thick winter clothing and hand warmers are essential. Snow boots are strongly recommended as roads freeze, and cars must have studless tires or chains. At Kusatsu Onsen Ski Resort, the newly installed "Pulse Gondola Tengu" (2023) allows you to enjoy the mountaintop view in seasons other than winter. Activities such as the zip line "BanZip TENGU" (about 500m at up to 70 km/h) and the 10m giant swing "Kusatsu Onsen SKY-SWING" are popular. The kids park has sled and snow racer slopes and a snow escalator, perfect for families.

section: Contact Information and Accommodation at Kusatsu Onsen
content: Inquiries about Kusatsu Onsen tourism are accepted at the Kusatsu Onsen Tourism Association (phone 0279-88-0800). For accommodation reservations and inquiries, the Kusatsu Onsen Ryokan Association (0279-88-3722, hours 9:00–18:00) or Kusatsu Onsen Sogo Kankosha (0279-88-2482, hours 9:00–20:00) can help, and they can introduce you to accommodations that match your needs. Kusatsu Onsen accommodations range from small inns for hot spring therapy to large hotels, with rates from around 7,000 yen to over 40,000 yen depending on your budget.

Hakone Onsen is located in Kanagawa Prefecture and is easily accessible from Tokyo. It is composed of multiple hot spring areas including Hakone-Yumoto, Gora, and Sengokuhara, and the "Hakone Seventeen Springs" offer different spring qualities and atmospheres by area. Spring qualities range from simple hot springs to sulfur and chloride springs. Museums, Lake Ashi, ropeways, and other tourist spots are well developed, and with many facilities offering day-trip bathing, it is suitable for short trips.

section: Beppu Onsen and Arima Onsen Overview
content: Beppu Onsen is located in Oita Prefecture and ranks first in Japan for both number of springs and output. It offers a very diverse range of spring qualities, and the "hell tour" is famous as a tourist attraction. It is ideal for long stays and enjoying hot spring hopping. Arima Onsen in Hyogo Prefecture is one of Japan's oldest hot springs, with two different spring qualities: "gold spring" and "silver spring." The gold spring is reddish-brown water rich in iron and salt that warms the body well, while the silver spring is colorless and transparent with low stimulation.

section: Types and Enjoyment of Day-Trip Bathing
content: "Day-trip bathing" (hot spring hopping) without staying overnight has roughly three styles. Public baths are simple bathhouses managed and used by locals, with fees of a few hundred yen, and you can experience local daily life. Day-trip hot spring facilities (like super sento) offer open-air baths, saunas, restaurants, and stone baths, suitable for spending the whole day. Drop-in baths at inns let you experience baths at high-end inns that normally cost tens of thousands of yen for about 1,000 yen to 2,000 yen. Useful items to bring include a plastic bag for wet towels, 100-yen coins for lockers and dryers in the changing room, and mini bottles of basic cosmetics. It is recommended to check reception hours, closed days, amenities, and crowd levels on the official website before visiting.

Before entering the bath, perform rinsing (kakeyu) to wash off dirt and acclimate your body to the water temperature. In the washing area, use the shower while seated and be considerate not to splash others. Keep towels out of the bath water; place them on your head or on the bath edge. If you have long hair, tie it up and keep it out of the water. Do not swim or make noise in the bath; soak quietly. When leaving for the changing room after bathing, wring out your towel in the bath area and dry yourself thoroughly before exiting. Most facilities prohibit smartphone use in the changing room to prevent voyeurism. For safety, avoid bathing after drinking alcohol, avoid staying in too long, and hydrate before and after bathing.

Onsen can be enjoyed differently each season. In spring, cherry blossom viewing baths in open-air baths with cherry trees are recommended; lukewarm baths around 38–40°C are said to be good for relaxing. In summer, "indifferent temperature bathing" in springs around 36°C (near body temperature) is effective for preventing summer fatigue, and you can enjoy cool breezes after bathing at higher-elevation resorts. Bicarbonate springs leave skin feeling refreshed after bathing, making them suitable for summer. In autumn, open-air baths with autumn foliage are exceptional, especially at dusk when the sky and leaves create a fantastical view. Winter is the peak season for onsen; "snow-viewing baths" in hot water while snow falls are a quintessential Japanese winter experience. In winter, be careful of heat shock from sudden temperature changes; be thorough with rinsing and acclimate from your feet gradually.

section: Spring Quality Guide by Recommended Users
content: The recommended spring quality depends on the person. Simple hot springs have low stimulation and allow long bathing; they are ideal for onsen beginners, children, the elderly, and those with sensitive skin, with efficacy for fatigue recovery, neuralgia, and insomnia. Sulfur springs have strong antibacterial effects and suit those with chronic skin conditions, atopic dermatitis, or acne, but they are highly stimulating so those with sensitive skin should take care. Bicarbonate springs are called "beauty skin springs" and smooth the skin; they are recommended for those interested in beauty or with dry skin. Chloride springs have high heat-retention effects and are especially suited for those with cold sensitivity or who get cold easily in winter. Acid springs have very strong antibacterial effects and are effective for athlete's foot and chronic dermatitis, but they are highly stimulating to the skin, so rinsing with plain water after bathing is recommended. Radioactive springs (radium springs) are said to boost natural healing and are used for those with gout, rheumatism, or chronic digestive disorders. Choosing the right spring quality for your purpose can maximize the benefits of onsen.
